column4: Hi guys, I was wondering if anyone could point me to an explenation of why compiled source is specific to each machine. Or is it? Can you compile source on one machine for use on another machine (just copying the binaries)?
it depends how you compile it
hmm, Can you give me some buzz wards that I can google to learn more?
you could tell the compiler to use some instructions that is only available on your CPU,  but not others, hence the compiled binary can only be executed on your cpu
you could also tell the compiler to use generic instructions that works for all cpu
like this http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/gcc-optimization.xml
would that disicion be mad in the source or on the command line at compile time?
not the source, but how you compile it
icarus-c ok, cool! Thanks
so if you had two of the same machines, you could compile any way and still copy between systems?
yes.
it is just about cpu model
that is the only thing that separates computers?
like, core2,  pentium4, athlon64....etc
Right. Thanks! :)
different cpu family has different features and instructions.
you could optimize for one to make it run faster on that specific cpu,  but may not run at all on other cpu
can you optimize for another cpu other than the in the computer you compile on so it can be used on a slower one?
yes i think. never tried though
but you can't use gcc's "native" autodetection
I think the term "cpu optimize" for google will do nicely! :)
